title.narrative: Subsistence to Self-Reliance - Bringing the Power of Markets to Africa’s Lowest-Income Farmers

description.narrative: Founded in 2006, One Acre Fund exists to pursue two core passions: 1) serving the world’s lowest-income populations, smallholder farmers, and 2) developing a market-based solution that dignifies them as paying customers rather than aid recipients. Through our comprehensive ‘market in a box,’ we bring the power of markets directly to rural smallholders. We deliver farm inputs on credit, facilitate flexible repayment, conduct weekly in-field farm trainings, provide post-harvest and market support, and extend protective crop insurance. Unlike traditional charities, our solution interacts with farmers as paying customers. This gives them a commanding voice in our program delivery, and enables a long-term sustainable business model. Importantly, our bundled approach delivers powerful, measurable results for our farmers (the majority of whom are women): within one planting season, they increase their farm income by 50% or more, and begin a swift pathway from subsistence to self-reliance. Since inception, One Acre Fund has pursued the steady expansion of our solution, launching full-scale operations in six East African countries: Kenya, Rwanda, Burundi, Tanzania, Malawi, and Uganda. Yet with 50 million hungry farm households in Sub-Saharan Africa, we remain small against the problem we are trying to solve. Therefore, we are now working to grow as fast as we can, and by the end of 2017, we have an ambitious vision to serve 550,000 farm families, encompassing over two million children. Importantly, as we achieve this new level of growth, the cost-efficiency of our solution will also dramatically increase. We will steadily increase our sustainability (% of costs covered by farmer repayments) through increased economies of scale, requiring only $20 USD in donor subsidy to extend our complete ‘market in a box’ to each rural farm family by the end of 2017. The Dutch Government is serving as an anchor funder to help fuel our growth to this next level of scale and efficiency, providing €4m EUR in program support over two years (2016 and 2017). This support will enable us to also raise an additional €15m EUR in grants for our core program, and to earn an additional €68m EUR in repayments from the farmers we serve. This funding will propel One Acre Fund toward key organizational milestones: in 2017, we plan to serve over half a million farm families, at over 80% financial sustainability. Importantly, this support will place us on a strong trajectory to achieve our 2020 goal: alleviating hunger and poverty for one million farm families.

comment.narrative: Decrease from original $130 target due to significant drought org-wide and especially in Kenya in 2016, which greatly affected core maize yields.

Based on our updated data, our clients generated an average of $102.3 in new income in 2016. Though our impact suffered, we achieved our target of enabling a 50% improvement in profit on supported activities - which made a powerful and tangible difference in the lives of our clients.

The season’s harvest has been completed across most of One Acre Fund's country programs, and our rigorous impact measurement activities are now underway. Preliminary findings suggest that we will boost farmers' 2017 incomes from supported activities by 50%, unlocking an average of $125 in new profits per client. We attribute this strong figure to improved training compliance, favorable weather, and our organization's rapid response to the maize pest fall armyworm.

One Acre Fund had a year of strong, above-target impact across our core program, achieving an estimated $170 in incremental income on supported activities, representing a 66% improvement over control farmers. We attribute these results to improved rainfall patterns, a rapid and effective response to fall armyworms’ emergence, and key programmatic improvements (including a greater focus on 1:1 farmer training to boost planting compliance). Further investments in high-impact add-on products, including trees and solar lights, helped bolster our impact this season.

comment.narrative: In 2017, One Acre Fund delivered life-changing farm inputs to a total of 614,800 farm families, despite registering a decline in the growth of our Core Program, from 46% in 2016 to 38%. Our core growth performance can be attributed to enrollment shortfalls in our newer country programs, predominantly the result of external challenges. In Malawi and Zambia, for instance, low 2017 maize prices resulted in program enrollment rates that were lower than expected.

While our dollar (absolute) impact dipped in 2016 due to adverse weather conditions, preliminary data shows that we still achieved our percentage impact target relative to non-clients as a result of improved agricultural practices, crop insurance payouts, and impactful non-agricultural technologies. Final 2016 impact data will be reported in Q2 2017.

comment.narrative: Preliminary estimates show that One Acre Fund experienced below-target sustainability of 69.4% in 2017. This shortfall can be attributed to both internal and external circumstances that arose in 2017. Externally, government restrictions on input pricing in Rwanda and Tanzania, a maize export ban in Zambia that reduced sales prices and affected our clients’ ability to repay their loans, and unexpected costs resulting from our response to the onset of fall armyworm all contributed to our 2017 sustainability outcome. In-house, below-target adoption of high-margin solar products in Rwanda and slower-than-anticipated enrollment in Zambia both resulted in shortfalls against expected revenue. Additionally, we deliberately opted to “double down” on investments in “inward” (existing site) growth within Kenya, our most impact-efficient program in terms of social return on investment (SROI). We are optimistic this will result in greater scale and total impact by 2020, at the cost of a near-term dip in program sustainability. Despite these challenges, our core program generated ~$5 in new farmer income for every $1 of donor subsidy in 2017, which we believe is industry leading cost effectiveness for the population we serve.

2017 year-end financial data indicated that we registered a decline on financial sustainability from 73% in 2016 to 69%, which fell meaningfully below our 82% target for the season. These shortfalls have been a result of many factors among them: the roll-out of two new country operations (Malawi and Uganda, which are inherently less cost-efficient in early years); drought effects in Kenya; and adjustments to new government regulations in Rwanda and Tanzania.

Slight decrease in original target due to lower than expected margins in Rwanda (as a result of newly rolled-out government regulations which limit program fees we are able to charge). We now expect to surpass 80% sustainability in 2017 vs 2016.

Our audited financial data indicates that in 2016, we covered approximately 73% of our total field expenses with farmer repayments, which falls meaningfully below our 78% target for the season. This anticipated shortfall was primarily driven by the repayment challenges that we experienced in Uganda, due to the season’s drought, and Rwanda, largely due to the announcement of a new government policy for subsidizing farm inputs, which led to confusion among our farmers around our long-standing loan repayment norms.

Target exceeded. At every level of our organization, we have a dedicated and diligent team who embody the ethos of One Acre Fund. This is especially true of our brilliant local field agents, without whom we might never realize our vision. With the consistent year on year growth of our core program, there is a constant need for driven, well-trained staff. As such, we successfully expanded our team of staff to 5,270 members in 2017. This rapid rise in our team size can be attributed to the streamlining of our rigorous five-step process for recruiting and interviewing candidates, as well as new staffing policies, which came into force in 2017.

comment.narrative: Revised from original proposal target of 420,000 farm families served in 2016.
Exceeded our 2016 org-wide target for farmers served due to especially strong growth in our Kenya and Rwanda programs.

We are on track to achieve above-target scale of 583k+ clients by year-end, translating to healthy 30% growth from 2016. This rapid growth is partly due to our substantial scale-up in Rwanda, where a government push to boost agricultural input adoption has required input distributors (including One Acre Fund) to remove fees/interest from these life-changing products, significantly increasing demand for our program.

Target exceeded. One Acre Fund achieved another year of above-target growth in 2017, serving over 614,800 smallholder families across six core countries and two pilot programs. Our strong results were largely driven by high enrollment in Rwanda, following the removal of interest and service fees. This helped offset enrollment shortfalls in Kenya, where a drought in late 2016 suppressed farmer yields and temporarily led to below-average expansion. Overall, however, One Acre Fund saw 38% program growth by year end, delivering our life-changing bundle of goods and services to thousands of farm families. In the future, we look forward to broadening the scope of our promising pilot in Zambia, which served 7,200 farmers in 2017, and continuing to explore and evaluate opportunities in Myanmar.
